title: 107_s502
content: The Act titled as the "Indian Needs Assessment and Program Evaluation Act of 2001" is established for the purpose of findings and objectives. Congress finds that the United States has a trust obligation to provide services to Indian tribes and Indians, but federal departments have not provided adequate information to assess these programs, hindering Congress's ability to address the needs of the tribes. The Act aims to ensure that Indian needs for Federal programs and services are known in a predictable manner, review and monitor the effectiveness of these programs, promote cooperation and coordination among Federal departments, and enhance accountability in providing assistance to Indians. The Act aims to provide technical and business development assistance to Indians and furnish Congress with reliable information on Indian needs and the evaluation of Federal programs and services for Indians nationwide. SEC. 3. INDIAN TRIBAL NEEDS ASSESSMENT. The Act requires the Secretary of the Interior to contract with an entity to conduct immediate needs assessments for Indian tribes in consultation with various government agencies. The Environmental Protection Agency and other relevant Federal departments are tasked with developing a uniform method for assessing the program and service needs of Indian tribes and Indians. This includes determining service area locations and sizes, as well as the total population of tribes in those areas. The contractor must consult with tribal governments to establish and conduct needs assessments, considering factors like total population of other tribes in the service area, availability of similar programs, and socio-economic conditions. Federal departments must conduct ongoing needs assessments every 5 years in coordination with the Secretary of the Interior. The Indian Needs Assessment (INA) is conducted by federal departments in coordination with the Secretary of the Interior to determine the needs of Indian tribes and eligible individuals for programs and services. The assessment must be submitted to relevant congressional committees by February 1 when required. Additionally, federal agencies must evaluate Indian tribal programs within 180 days of the assessment. The Secretary of the Interior must develop a uniform method and criteria for compiling and reporting information on annual expenditures for programs and services for which Indians are eligible, including details on participating tribes, applications, and terminated programs. The Secretary of the Interior must develop a uniform method and criteria for compiling and reporting information on annual expenditures for programs and services benefiting Indians, including details on participating tribes, applications, terminated programs, and the delivery of services and funding by each department or agency. Each Federal department or agency providing services to Indian tribes must submit an Annual Indian Program Evaluation (AIPE) to specific Congressional committees. By February 1 each year, these departments must list all programs and services available to Indian tribes in the Federal Register. Confidentiality of information obtained from Indian tribes for program evaluations must only be used for purposes outlined in the Act. SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of the Interior must develop and submit a report to Congress within 2 years detailing the coordination of Federal program assistance for Indian tribes. Within 30 months, a Strategic Plan for Federal Assistance coordination with Indian tribes must be filed, including necessary law reforms. The report to Congress must include reforms needed for Federal program assistance coordination with Indian tribes, proposals for implementing the reforms, and any other recommendations consistent with the Act's purposes. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2002 and beyond to carry out the Act.
